Sheez....Mr Veale....put a snip in it, you already got too many!!
Six and the eldest is hardly 10 years.

comment._content: Such a great photograph.  And the comments here are hilarious!

comment._content: makes you wonder how many more they had after this photo!

comment._content: A wonderful old portrait such quality.
comment.authorname: Christine Rose.., Huge Thanks To All My Flick'r Fr

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Well, you're all very pass-remarkable! :)

But have to agree - my eyes were out on stalks as I quickly calculated that this must have been nearly one child per year, and there may have been even more children if one or two did not survive infancy...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Yep indeed, as a fine strapping woman....Mrs. Veale's fecundity knows no bounds! It would not be surprising to know if there's another 'bun in the oven' when this pic was taken?

I would probably let out a subdued chuckle if I was beside her in a grocery shop as she asked for "two dozen eggs". Of course, the shopkeeper would probably reply "....and would they be large eggs, Madam?" then there'd be no restraining me (LOL).

But seriously though, it's shocking to think that large family sizes were once held in high esteem without much thought to the toll taken from the mother's well-being and health from childbirth year after year and then the work in rearing a large number of children.

comment.author: 38020241@N07
comment._content: Cuando observamos una foto,en este caso bien antigua(casi un siglo),  casi todos, me incluyo,la vemos de manera diferente... Nuestra mirada es pues, la mirada de personas de este siglo,en 2011,con todo lo que ello conlleva al ver imagenes que tienen que ver con nuestros antepasados...Sin duda,cada quien lo hace tomando una apreciacion sobre lo que la foto en si misma dice... Una familia numerosa ? si,lo era, una hermosa familia, y bellamente retratada.Me congratulo de ver estas imagenes,porque se convierte en realidad el axioma que dice"Una imagen vale mas que mil palabras"...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Estás en lo correcto, asixtoromero! Cada imagen vale más que mil palabras ...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Well John, if he was able to afford a studio portrait of the family, then they certainly were not living in poverty...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 44089209@N08
comment._content: The comments are humourous indeed.   Lets not forget that this photo was taken before modern birth control, at a time when everyone, the church, the family, the government, likely pushed for big families,  and when thoughts of having to send all of them to university didn`t matter.  Besides, they`re mostly girls!  They`ll just get married off, no need to educate them!  It was a different world.

comment.author: 62379908@N00
comment._content: This is a normal size family for 1925.  My mother was one of six and my father one of eight.  Both were born in the first decade of the 20th century.  As recently as 1957 to 1965, my wife and I had four. But none of them had more than two. No great grandchildren yet.

comment.author: 94924767@N00
comment._content: Hmm thats nothing, my Great grandmother was one of 9 girls!

comment.author: 7517351@N05
comment._content:
I just stumbled across this photo while browsing through the many brilliant photos on here. It appears this photo was taken in the same studio as a photo I was given recently as part of a course, to restore and colour. The props (ball, racket, footstool, chair etc) are all the same, as are the poses. See below, 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/richiesphotos/9137876349/]

comment.author: 7517351@N05
comment._content: PS, the photo was also titled "family 1924", so they are within a year of eachother.
